Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned to see the fascinating and surprisingly understandable importance of technology and physics in my daily life, and did more math than I've done in years.

A broad overview to the wonderful world of technology! This class was truly fascinating and was basically split into three types of technologies, each in accordance with a different type of physics - electricity and magnetism, optics, and quantum mechanics. I can now confidently explain the mechanics behind 50+ different technologies to someone with any background, which is an incredible testament to the professor's ability.
lots of practical physics knowledge

None; this course was characterized mostly by finding answers to random physics problems that did not contribute to a solid understanding of the underlying processes nor inform on how other technological processes might work. More than anything, it did not build the ability to look at technological processes not covered by the course, and be able to understand them on our own. For non-STEM majors, this would have been a great takeaway from the course. Unfortunately, there were none.
You get a very good understanding of how most electronic technology works, in addition to some higher level math stuff.
I learned to never trust the course description because this course was not for non-science majors; it was insanely difficult
You learn about the physics of the modern world.
Learned a lot about how basic physics principles can explain a great deal of the technology we interact with every day.
understanding of technology

I didn't think I'd learn much in this class, but looking back, I'm surprised at how much more I know about how the world around us works! It's cool to walk around my daily life and notice phenomena I'd never remark upon before.
This course was extremely interesting because we learned how the physics behind everyday technology is actually quite simple once you understand the underlying principles.
I can now explain some of the most common technologies that we all use with physics concepts!
I learned how lots of things work!!!!
Basic scientific literacy. A greater knowledge of the way technology works.

This course teaches the basic technology/mechanisms behind many modern technologies that we use every day. There are weekly psets based on what was taught in class, though many questions on them (each pset has an average of 4 multi-part questions) push you to extrapolate from these concepts and apply them in a more advanced way. For this, you should attempt the problems then go to office hours to think through them with other students and Professor Miller, who is really kind and willing to take time explaining things if you show you're making an effort. You're allowed one page of your own notes for the exams, but that does not mean they're easy. In fact, the exams are fairly challenging if you don't have a strong science background, especially in physics. It's not the most fun science/QR, but it's also pretty useful if you want to know (basically) how things work.

ENAS 110 teaches you to see the underlying physical principles behind most current technology, from cameras to phones to the internet. Throughout the course we reviewed physics concepts involving electromagnetism, quantum mechanics and optics, and applied them to modern technological developments. This course helped me, a physicist, understand the appied side of what I had been studying with more theoretical approaches. This class is wonderful!
Not in a million years.
This class was terrible, but I did learn the basic physics behind a lot of everyday uses of electromagnetics, optics, and wave theory.

This class teaches the ins and outs of all of the technology we have around us every day -- cell phones, radio waves, colors, vision -- and a basic physical explanation of the phenomena. It was an awesome new way to think about things that I never thought about before!
I learned about a lot of the technology behind every day things that I use.

A working knowledge of the core technologies in our everyday lives and the basic scientific principles behind them. It did not require any math past algebra and was focused on conceptual explanations rather than the dense calculations.
Learned a lot about the fundamentals of how things work.
I learned a lot about physics & how physics is used as the basis for much of today's technology
I learned about the science behind many different technologies. The largest insight I gained was how much science goes into the small technologies.
Very rudimentary applied physics; the physics behind how a lot of technology around us actually works.
Gained an understanding of how the world works
Basic understanding of how certain technologies (LEDs, TVs, optical fibers, encryption, colors) work
Basic mathematical and theoretical skill as well as applied conceptual knowledge of the rudimentary functions of physics that serve as the basis for many common, modern day technologies.

As a social sciences major, I personally learned a lot! Now I have much more appreciation for the technologies surrounding us, their complexity, and science in general! Developed some quant skills and intuition in physics, especially electromagnetism and optics.

This class is meant to teach the math and physics behind a variety of technologies. However, the breadth, pace, and wildly varying degrees of physics/math students are expected to understand throughout the course makes it difficult to organize many of the concepts and apply them usefully.
A knowledge of the basis of all of modern technology.
None.  This class was an absolute waste of my time.

Really good conceptual understanding of so many phenomena around us. This course was focused more on concepts and less on extremely hard mathematical equations which I appreciated and found very interesting.
Good lectures and psets, midterms sometimes too hard.

This course is incredible. The professor is the most caring and charismatic of any I've had at Yale, the assignments are fair (1-2 hours a week for most problem sets), the exams are doable, and the lectures are gripping. I would have liked for the class to be a bit more mathematically rigorous, but given that this is a no prerequisite QR course, that's to be expected. Exams are a bit long but fair. For me, this was a very enjoyable SC credit taken in addition to a heavy course load, and it was never too stressful.
for a class targeted at non-STEM majors, it relied heavily on previous exposure to a lot of complex STEM concepts.

The strengths lay in TA's helping with problem sets; however, they were unable to help with understanding the larger trends of the course (not their own fault, but because of how they course was designed. They were unable to participate or give much input). 

The weaknesses were many. While the instructor was not inherently terrible, the way he designed the course made his lectures extremely unhelpful nor insightful. The main weakness was that there was no consistent source from which topics could be studied and learned. For a course that is essentially a college physics course (though I would not put it at that level, because those courses are much more organized and have much more resources), this course had little to no consistent source of information. Material would be introduced in lecture, but problem sets would be exponentially more difficult and complex. While this would be fine in any other course, the issue was that there was no where to turn to learn more, other than "google" as we were constantly referred to. This led to long searches through obscure websites for answers to specific questions that did nothing to further our understanding of the topic at whole. There was no textbook, which would have been extremely helpful to turn to for an understanding of what the heck was going on. Again, the instructor would probably have been able to teach sufficiently well from a textbook, but given the course structure, he was of little to no help. It was frustrating, especially considering that many students were struggling and dissatisfied, and very little was done to remediate the larger underlying issues (though the mid semester review did yield some positive results, like a slower pace). However, a slower pace with more of the same just gave us more time to slog through fewer subjects that were still poorly taught.
Good course, interesting topics

The strength of this course was its excellent syllabus, which related a lot of distinct concepts and gave an overview of a lot of modern technologies. 

The weakness of this course is the lack of a textbook and assumed knowledge of higher level math (lots of trig, natural log, and more that isn't covered in class).
I appreciated when we started with a tangible product, such as MRI, and then learned the underlying concepts, as opposed to learning the underlying concepts abstractly and applying them later.
This course is deceptively difficult. I think it would be better if it were MORE math intensive and less descriptive.

At the beginning, the course was much more difficult and the slides were less comprehensive. There is definitely a huge disconnect between the difficulty of material presented in lecture and the psets. However, the professor was receptive to feedback, made the material easier and gave students more resources for help. The TAs weren't very helpful and present. There should be additional resources and support, especially for students who don't come from a STEM background.

Strengths: Prof. Miller is a really great professor and was very helpful in listening to the general consensus about the pace of the course. In addition, there were a lot of opportunities for office hours and the graded material felt very representative of what we were supposed to be learning in this course. 

Weaknesses: The problem sets could definitely have been tougher and pushed our understanding of the material to a greater extent, especially since the exams were very difficult. It often felt like I'd breeze through the problem sets smoothly, but then be stuck on an exam question because I didn't understand the material to a sufficient depth.
done well
Prof Miller already knows this, but the first part of the course (the EM stuff) was significantly more difficult than the rest of the course. I think maybe we should have taken it more slowly.

The course is truly accessible to someone without much of a physics background (e.g. me). I really appreciated the class notes that Professor Miller posts for every class. That said, some of the problem sets were very challenging, and I had to resort to Google to try to answer them. I wish he had gone over problem set problems in class as he did later in the course much earlier. I also wish we went over the math more because though equations can be intimidating, I believe they can really be used to explain more abstract concepts that are hard to grasp.

The program of the course is exciting and engaging. I feel that I learned about many things which effect me on a daily basis. In terms of pacing, I thought the first unit of the course moved a little too quickly.

The course was well-designed and well-taught. By the middle of the semester, Professor Miller had established a good pace for the lectures and a fair  structure for the exams. The psets were manageable and instructive, though many questions would be difficult to do without outside guidance, I think. More in-class demonstrations, if possible, could be helpful to visualize/see the processes we discuss in action.

I don't see any ways to improve this course. It is extremely organized, comprehensive, clear and helpful. The course materials, including lectures, Canvas pages and Piazza posts were helpful every time, and professor Miller was attentive to every signle request. His midterm survey to the students helped alleviate any (remember, small) concerns from the students. Overall a fantastically well organized class that I would not change in any way,

This class, for m, was terrible. The content was haphazard and seemed not to follow any real path; rather it seemed to be various incongruent ideas heaped on top of each other. I think this class could certainly be improved by developing a curriculum that builds upon itself rather than being a mishmosh of ideas and technology.

The course was advertised for non-STEM people who didn't have much science background. However, a lot of those type of people got buried early in the course because even the "basic" physics was too much for them. It's hard to really offer a full experience of what this course was meant for without doing that... but if it's going to be advertised as such, maybe make it more of a survey and breadth class rather than sciences.

The course was marketed as being for non-STEM majors, yet focused very intensely on specific formulas and physics properties. The topics were very interesting, but some topics seemed to go too in depth for non-STEM majors.
second half was taught much better after more lecture slides, piazza, reviews.

I thought the second half of the course was a big improvement from the first. Professor Miller took our suggestions from the mid-term evaluations and after that, the work was far more manageable and easy to follow along with.

The course was structured well, with topics that Professor Miller found personally interesting and using a series of smaller ideas to explain a larger phenomenon (ie. learning optics and how LCD displays work first to later explain the basics of virtual reality) The homework was much more focused on calculations than the exams were and could be better aligned.

Strengths: lots of interesting topics and information. 
Weaknesses: it started off unstructured and it wasn't clear what the course required.

The course does teach you about different technologies which is a plus and all of the material after the first midterm did not assume too much previous physics knowledge. The changes that were implemented after the first midterm were helpful and should be kept. One other area it could be improved is the tests were very specific and did not seem to evaluate the broader concepts but specifics of certain concepts that were not stressed as much in lecture.

The first half of the course was very very rough--it felt like the professor was presuming a much higher level of knowledge than we had going into it, and a lot of the stuff in lecture/on the problem sets was very challenging. The second half of the course was better (but it almost slowed down too much...). I think a HUGE improvement would be making tfs/office hours a little more of an accessible resource, especially because a lot of people that take the class are going into it with really really rudimentary background knowledge. Also having comprehensive lecture notes to look at outside of class would be wonderful (by the end the "pages" he would post after lecture kind of filled that role, but they still weren't comprehensive...).
Could be structured better

The course started out a little more difficult than anticipated but the professor was surprisingly willing to adjust as needed based on the class. The strength of the course is really Prof Miller; he was super willing to explain anything about the problem sets or exams during office hours or schedule another time if you couldn't make office hours, and took surveys during the course and actually adapted the material/level of difficulty for the class. I just wish I had gone to talk to him sooner he really wants students to understand what's going on and will go out of his way so that everyone at least has a basic understanding. If I had another Sc or QR requirement to finish I would definitely try to take one of his classes to fulfill it.

The biggest problem I had with this course was that it tried to cover ~a lot ~ of material very quickly - spending less than a lecture on quantum, etc. If the class focused on a few central technologies and went very in depth, I think it would have worked a lot better. Prof. Miller, to his credit, did a great job responding to student feedback, but I think there were larger structural issues with the course that couldn't be fixed with cosmetic changes. Also - maybe this isn't the best forum for this, but I'm really frustrated by the lack of QR seminars. I learned long ago that lectures are not a good way for me to learn unless I'm already fascinated in the material, and considering courses like this are supposed to be designed for non-STEM majors with limited background in the material, a wider range of types of QR/science courses is something Yale should aim for. For people who deliberately chose not to do STEM because of the large technical lectures but would still like to engage in the material, finding that the only QR credits available are large technical lectures is really, really frustrating.

The Course was a very interesting, slightly challenging options for non-applied science/engineers to get a good depth of insight into the complexities and intricacies of the subject area without requiring them to sacrifice too much focus to their primary area of study.

The course is definitely not a gut (even though it might first appear to be that way), and shouldn't be advertised like that. Some prior exposure to physics (even AP Physics) is definitely very helpful and assumed for some topics. Apart from that, this is a great course.

I felt that this course was often taught at a much higher level than it was marketed, and as a science credit for non-STEM majors often touched on complex subjects with little fundamental explanation. I was often frustrated by the complexity of the p-sets compared to the relatively simple level of physics taught in the lecture.

This class was the worst academic experience of my time at Yale. As someone who is not in a stem major but still has taken four QR credits, I was not expecting a walk in the park for this SC/QR, but I also was not expecting to find the work impossible. The level of conceptual work expected in this class makes it difficult for anyone who does not already have an intuition for physics/technology. I really would not recommend if you are just "interested" in the material (as I was) and not already experienced in it.
Great material although very challenging. Information was hard to find after lecture.
Lecture was poorly organized, Psets were confusing and unrelated to lecture, Prof Miller was unsympathetic and graded very harshly.
A great and engaging science credit for non-majors, you'll learn interesting and useful things. Not too much work or stress if you're comfortable with high school physics/trig.

Please, take this course. Professor Miller is incredible, the material is fascinating, and you will be able to impress your family at the dinner table in explaining how things work. Grading is fair, workload is reasonable, and lectures are engaging. What more could you want?
no.

Never in a million years would I recommend this course to another student. Taking this course was among the worst decisions I have made while at Yale and I would not wish it upon anyone else. Unless you enjoy taking poorly organized/taught courses that consume incredible amounts of time without yielding any benefits, this course is not for you. If you're reading this, and are considering taking this course because it's the only one that fits into your schedule, do anything other than this course. Please.
No. Not very basic, physics concepts are not explained very well and they can get complicated. find a better Sc credit.
Probably could have been quite interesting and not that bad, but the material is unorganized and it was so hard to go and sit through lecturesss
Solid science credit
Yes, provided they know what they're getting into; this is not a gut course, and although it is rewarding material, it's pretty difficult.
No- though Professor Miller is very helpful during office hours, I do not think I learned a large amount in this class.
No. Deceptively difficult.  More descriptive and conceptual than math based. Not terrible though, and you do learn some interesting things, although I am not sure how useful the gained knowledge is.

Do not take this class if you are looking for an easy science gut. It's not. It's challenging, however you do learn a lot and the practical application is extremely interesting. However, be prepared to be challenged! If you're willing to work, then I would still take it. The professor is great, once you understand the level of work required.

I'd definitely recommend it if you're looking for a good science credit and have a decently strong quantitative intuition. A lot of people took this course expecting it to be a science gut but it's actually rather difficult. Not very time intensive but the exams will definitely push your understanding. That being said, I'd only take this if you're actually interested in the material and aren't too worried about grades. I found the course interesting and Prof. Miller's office hours to be abundant and extremely helpful, but if you don't find the material interesting and don't try to understand it on a deeper level then it will be a frustrating class.
yes, it was interesting

This class is not a gut, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't take it. I was surprised to find that I ended up learning a lot and that the class has actually changed how I go about the world in small ways (every time I see someone wearing glasses, I try to see whether they're nearsighted or farsighted based on what their lenses show. and every time I see a puddle with an oiI film, I always think about iridescence...) You'll learn a lot, but there was more work than I would have liked. Also, the exams can be tough, mainly because of the time constraint. It was also kind of annoying that psets only counted for 20% even though they often took a while to complete.
yes.

If you want a science credit, I believe that this course is one of the most fulfilling courses that you can take. That said, I think that it is definitely harder than other science credits (just because of the nature of physics).
Yes, you learn a lot.
Yes. This course is a good way to learn about the world of technology around you!

Yes, I would recommend it. The material can be somewhat dry at points, but if you remember that what you learn affects basically everything in your everyday life, then it's okay. This is not a gut and requires work, but if you do well on the psets and study for the exams, you can do well.
If you are looking for a Science gut, then this is not the class for you. With that being said, however, Tech World was a well taught class that covered some very interesting material.

YES! ENAS 110 teaches many, many technology-related concepts, bringing together theorists and experimentalists alike. Please take this and enjoy Professor Miller's fantastic organization and passion for teaching <3

I would not recommend this class to any Yale student. If you are not the STEM type and looking for an easy Sci class, there are plenty more out there that are more interesting and easier. If you are a STEM type, there is likely no need to take a physics class such as this one. I am not one to criticize a class unjustly, but I do not want to mince words: This class was, at least for me, a non-STEM person, a complete travesty that I wish I had never taken. Unless something about it seriously improves, don't take this class.

I totally recommend this course to people who have somewhat of a STEM background. It was incredible to broaden my horizons and get new perspectives on the "technology" I use every day... but the math and physics is a step above "basic" so you definitely need to be STEM oriented.
Yes, the topics covered were interesting.
Yes, if its taught like it was post midterm 1.

Definitely. This is the type of course that is very practical and the knowledge you gain from class makes you immediately see every day objects a little differently since you now know how it works. It is not math intensive and Professor Miller's personal expertise in solar panels and VR makes it much more interesting than other physics courses.
I would, but only go in knowing you have to be very organized and ready to be the one asking questions.
if you dont have a strong physics background, tread lightly. this class can be tough.
Yes, especially people without a strong physics/engineering background-- very accessible!

I would probably not recommend it to someone who has not taken physics before because there were a number of students in the class that had which gave them an advantage on the tests and in the class in general.

No; there are much more interesting science credits out there that are way better organized. Yes some of the stuff we learned was cool, but that definitely didn't make up for the frustrating way the course was laid out.
Not as much of a gut as I expected, but not the worst class either
Yes, I took it for a requirement and Prof. Miller is great.

Are there any gut QRs anymore? The workload's manageable but (at least as it was taught this year), it's a lot of material very quickly. Prof. Miller did improve the course as the semester went on but it's still frustrating less in a wow-I'm-learning-things way and more in a 'this would be really interesting if we had more time to spend on it but instead we spent 5 minutes on it in lecture and now I just need to finish this pset' way.
Yes, it was a good class to add to an already full schedule without stretching one's self too thin.
Yes, definitely a very good introductory/overview course in applied physics, if you're prepared to spend a few extra hours doing work.

No, especially not if you're a non-STEM major looking for a science credit. The grading curve is unfair (i.e. almost nonexistent) because there are a lot of STEM majors looking for an "easy" class, which throws the curve.
I would not recommend this course if you do not have intermediate (AP+), recent experience with physics.
Absolutely. Very interesting course material.

Do not take this class.  It is an idiotic class that is both uninteresting, tedious, confusing, frustrating, and too much work.  I would have learned more watching Khan academy (which I did way too much in order to complete the PSets)

Really good introductory science and engineering course. covered a wide span of phenomena and  devices. the professor had good slides and even better presentaion. He always tried to keep us engaged in class. He even brought a parabolic reflector when we were learning about them. If you have no love for science dont take this course. But even if you love science a little take it
